description.narrative:
Partner Name: Save Cambodia#s Wildlife (SCW) As one of the Non-Governmental Organizations (NGOs) that works for Cambodia#s natural resource protection, Save Cambodia#s Wildlife (SCW) is a premier National Conservation non-government organization that works specifically on nature conservation and biodiversity preservation. Since its creation in 2000 SCW has been responsible for a large and diverse territory that covers many provinces of Cambodia. SCW has been highly successful with a range of projects including the provision of technical support and increasing environmental awareness among the general public through teaching programs, publications, andenvironmental awareness campaigns.
SCW has been working on a firm belief that providing education and increasing public awareness in environmental issues are fundamental to conservation. Therefore our primary focus has been on education as a key to conservation.We continue to address environmental issues by disseminating accurate information and knowledge to the local communities and other stakeholders and networking among them.
Project Tittle: Increasing resilience of vulnerable small scale farmers, especially women through livelihood and economic activities
This project is being proposed to be implemented in Kampot and Kep province. The overall objectives of this project are to: 1. Increase resilience of vulnerable small scale farmers, especiall women through promoting womenentrepreneurship for livelihood and economic activitie; 2. Assist landless families, especially women, to access to safe and profitable financial service so that they can grow their independency in income earning for their livelihoods To achieve the mentioned objectives , SCW will apply the ILO tool kit on the entrepreneurism to delivery the Community-Based Enterprise Development (C-BED) training to SfC groups, and materialize Oxfam#s existing women#s leadership training module and use to build political leadership of those groups and will use its SfC experience to establish 20 new SfC groups of 300 members targeting landless and small holder farmers.

sector.narrative: The right to a sustainable livelihood
